results.title: Hubby gets a Hobby
results.brief_description:
This short film, ‘Hubby Gets a Hobby’, was directed by Keith Greenwood and presented by KenRa Films (Kenneth Rankine). The black-and-white, silent film pokes fun at the amateur film community (which Rankine was a part of) with a story of a husband taking up amateur cinematography as a hobby, much to his wife’s displeasure. The film’s comedic narrative comes from the husband’s obsessive focus on cameras and film equipment as his wife objects to his new hobby (demonstrating now-outdated gender stereotypes). By the end of the film, he is vindicated by capturing footage of a building fire, which is used in a newsreel, and eventually his wife is seen taking up a camera as well.

The film is notable for its footage of early models of consumer cameras, including 16mm hand-wound Bell and Howell and Kodak cameras. It also includes footage of the Victorian Amateur Cine Society filming a production about Captain Cook outside Cook’s Cottage in Fitzroy Gardens. According to an opening sequence title cards, the film was awarded a prize by the Victorian Amateur Cine Society in 1947.

Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

results.title: Grand Steeple Chase de Paris 1922
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This is a French Pathé Baby film, originally presented on 9.5mm film, ‘Grand Steeple Chase de Paris 1922’ from John Robertson Duigan’s collection.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows a group of film competing in a wheelbarrow race (one person holding another’s ankles while they walk with their hands); running; collecting water in a pail; playing with dogs; rowing on a river or lake; and picnicking and lounging on the grass with 1920s cars behind. The film then shows people on a golfcourse and three women and a dog in the gardens of a large home.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, features a group of people shaking hands, waving and blowing kisses to the camera, followed by a woman and dog in a garden, and possibly Duigan posing with their dog.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows a glimpse of the royal tour (the Duke of York’s car), followed by scenes of Duigan’s wife Kathleen playing with a child and a dog, including teaching the dog to stand on its hind legs and to jump for a stick.

results.title: [Ned Kelly cummerbund]
results.brief_description:
This collection of films has been generously donated by the Benalla Historical Society. The collection features moments in Benalla’s history and surrounding areas, including visits by the Governor of Victoria Sir Rohan Delacombe, ceremonies revealing various commemorative plaques, and the return of Ned Kelly’s cummerbund, thought to have been lost.

This silent footage shows a member of the Benalla Historical Society displaying the donated original green, bloodstained sash or cummerbund worn by Ned Kelly at the Glenrowan siege. The sash was given to Ned at the age of ten by a family whose child Ned saved from drowning. He was wearing it at the Glenrowan siege when captured in 1880. A doctor who tended to his wounds took it off while Ned was unconscious and kept it. The family then donated the sash in 1973 to the Benalla Historical Society. It is now on display in the Benalla Costume and Kelly Museum.

This film, likely captured for the purpose of editing, corresponds with interview footage of a news story for GMV-6 Shepparton.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:00:25:00 A member of the Benalla Historical Society presents the green sash
00:00:53:00 Close up showing supposed bloodstains
00:01:25:00 The member demonstrates how the sash is put on and worn
00:02:09:00 The member shows an old photograph of a man, perhaps the doctor who tended to Ned’s wounds
00:02:43:00 The member shows a violin made by John Nicholson in Benalla in 1905

results.title: Royal visit to Melbourne 1963 [Work print]
results.creator_credit: H. Rodney Power, David Swift and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: Work print footage of the royal visit in 1963. Includes aerial views of Melbourne, the arrival of the royal yacht, The Queen and Price Phillip being greeted by dignitaries, the inspection of troops, passing crowds in a Rolls Royce, the arrival at a racetrack and a reception at the Melbourne Town Hall

results.title: Royal visit to Melbourne 1963
results.creator_credit: H. Rodney Power, David Swift and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: Colour film record of the visit to Melbourne of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh. The three crowded, exciting days are show in detail. Includes the arrival of Her Majesty, presentation of the cup at the races at Flemington, a glittering State reception, service at Scot’s Church, Myer Music Bowl concert, Moomba parade, waving to country children en route to open the Royal Children’s Hospital, investiture at Government House, and farewell at the wharf.

results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This films shows the 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games, including the opening ceremony, athletes competing in events, decorations in the city and the arrival of Prince Philip to close the Olympic Games.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:51:00 Olympic sign featuring torch, ‘1956’ and the rings
00:08:27:00 cyclists on a velodrome
00:09:57:00 some spectacular diving at the Olympic Swimming Stadium
00:11:44:00 torch bearers running with the Olympic torch
00:13:45:00 the Opening Ceremony
00:20:10:00 Ron Clarke running into the stadium
00:21:00:00 Clarke lighting the cauldron
00:25:35:00 television broadcast vans including the Herald Sun, the ABC and GTV9
00:25:49:00 various track and field events
00:33:30:00 athletes walking up through the crowd of spectators
00:35:41:00 newspaper headlines for Betty Cuthbert’s win
00:41:47:00 Flinders Street Station decorated with the Olympic rings and flags
00:49:00:00 licence plate with Olympic rings
00:49:48:00 on the harbour for yachting
00:51:50:00 the arrival of Prince Philip
00:54:30:00 crowds, including people in costume
00:54:50:00 rows of parked 1950s cars
01:00:52:00 athletes sign autographs
01:02:01:00 a fallen cyclist is helped up by two officials
01:04:07:00 country flags lining a boulevard
01:11:12:00 a brass band
01:16:00:00 Olympic rings lit up at night
01:16:35:00 the closing ceremony

results.title: [Orsola: Teramo, 1960]
results.brief_description:
In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico Ciabarra, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine. The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia. The children that appear in the final sequence are related to the filmmaker.

Note: An excerpt from ‘Orsola: Teramo, 1960’ appears in ‘Innamorati’ (2001/3); a four minute digital storytelling work created by Roberta Ciabarra, ACMI Film Programer and daughter of Orsola and Ulderico, as part of a pilot workshop conducted at ACMI in 2001.For technical reasons a re-record of the narration was done in 2003.

Donor has requested that any de-accessioning of the 8mm film that it be returned to him or the family. File Note with Governance.
results.description:
A ‘day in the life’ of a young woman whose fiancé has emigrated to Melbourne, Australia. In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine.

The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia.

The related work “Innamorati” - made by Orsola’s daughter - tells the moving story of Orsola’s marriage and her journey to Australia to be reunited with her husband.
